title: GiveMeFive
segmentation: Hi my name is Laura and I'm presenting on the work of the group.
Give me 5 which was made up of data Annette catching myself and Francisco.

We were looking at rule based validation for collections of entities, so this is a very common real world problem where you have a set of a set of entities that you have to determine whether they meet a certain set of criteria and most traditional data management and information management systems encode the rules into the.
The data model, so they can't.
They're not very dynamic.
So we thought the link data.
Infrastructure is offered an opportunity to enable more dynamic.
Role modeling or rule validation and we had we were presented with a use case for this just this week at the summer school.
The tutors of the summer school asked us to form groups for our projects based on common interests, but they had a certain set of rules that we had to follow.
The groups had to be at least, you know, at least one member of each gender.
The people shouldn't be coming from the same institution or from the same country, shouldn't have this history of collaboration so.
We you know they reserve the right.
If we had a group that didn't meet these criteria to readjust us and we were thinking when we were getting together with our group that it would be nice if they had a really easy way to check that.
We all you know, all the groups met this criteria.
So we realized that all the false profiles that they asked us to create serendipitously included the information that was part of the rules.
And so we decided to use this.
4th data that everyone here created to build a rule generating system.
So what we?
Conceptualize the architecture of the system would be a web interface, a very simple user interface where the tutors could input the names of our proposed group.
And this would connect to web service which would in turn connect to a triple store.
In our instance the FOAF data.
And the names that were put into the web interface would create.
Sub graph, A named graph and the rules it would be encoded into separate sparkle queries that would then be.
Is against the graph.
Give back a set of results which would be sent back to the web service to show whether or not the group met the criteria.
So we like I said, a very simple web interface where you could just input the names.
And then.
Get back, you know whether or not the rules are met, so here this example shows that four of our five rules are met in this in this proposal, but one of them is not.
These people have written a paper together in the past, and therefore probably should not be working together.
So the rules that we had to work with.
In this group with the 4th data we had were very simple, just gender, country of origin or country where you were actually working now, and the Institute where you're working and these were the.
Very basic sparkle queries that were set up for.
That's this particular use case.
But what what we thought about for future work?
If we had a month to work on, this would be.
To make it a much more generic system.
So essentially what I was talking about in the beginning, creating an ability to dynamically.
Change the rules as needed.
Based on any particular use case, so we thought there were two possible approaches to enabling a dynamic rule set.
One of them would be too.
Query the existing data set that you're working with.
So in this instance the folks data and to draw back all of the properties that are in this data to say OK.
This is the data you have, and these are the properties from which you can generate rules.

That's the kind of limited option, because it's especially in this instance where the data that we were being asked to create was basically what was already proposed for the rules, and much more extensible way to create new rules would be to query external ontologies, either one or several, and again to do sort of the same thing to pull back the available properties in the ontology and the attributes.
So you would essentially have here ontology with its.
Properties.
And you'd select which ones you wanted and then you have an editor on the side to build out.
This is what the rule would be, which would then.
Be encoded into sparkle query by the web service.
Other features that would be kind of nice in time would be to have a user on this.
It's too light to see this image very well.
I apologize, but I have the user interface actually generated by the data so that you know if your rule was we want five slots.
The.
Interface would generate 5 slots or 4 or 10 or however many year rules said that you're you know you wouldn't have to manually enter names because they would be automatically populated by the data.

And the other thing we thought about giving more time would be to incorporate more external datasets in order to both clean up the existing data and to extend the information about the people to meet more rules.
So for example, we notice that a lot of people use city in their base near, but the rule was can come from the same country.
So if we had more time, we could say, OK, we're going to query DB pedia to find out what country the cities in and therefore add this data to the.
Profile and be able to use it.

Or one of the use cases we thought for collaboration was to query DB LP to determine whether or not projects have been worked on papers have been coauthored together in that way, so being able to gather even more information about users or about the students than what was provided in order to meet more rule cases, we thought too about other other use cases for this.
For example, you have a set of prerequisites for course.
In a school and you need to know whether the students who applied to be in the course of method prerequisites or you have a job.
You have applicants and you need to know whether they meet the minimum application requirements.
So.
That is essentially what we were.
You're proposing.
Thank you.
